results.title: Bruce almighty
results.creator_credit: Jim Carrey, Tom Shadyac, Spyglass Entertainment and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Local tv reporter Bruce Nolan doesn’t think that the world is treating him fairly. Then, after the worst day ever, Bruce angrily rails against God for ruining his life and mismanaging the universe. So God responds and endows Bruce with all of his powers to see if he can do a better job. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Morgan Freeman, Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, Catherine Bell.

results.title: Brown wolf
results.creator_credit: George Kaczender, Learning Corporation of America and International Cinemedia Center
results.brief_description: Adaptation of a Jack London story spotlighting the conflict between the call of the wild and civilization. A man attempts to shoot his dog in order to survive, but the dog escapes and is taken in by a young couple. Eventually the man returns and claims his dog, which chooses to return to the wild. Set in the early 1900’s. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Brown rot
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the nature and extent of the fruit disease know as “brown rot”. Illustrations include initial infection of the fruit; development of the mycelium and fruit bearing bodies, conidiophores; growth rings found in the affected areas of the fruit; transfer of the disease from fruit to fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J.V. Durden, Stephen Ackroyd and Shell Film Unit

results.title: Brown men and red sand
results.creator_credit: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: This film is part of the original silent film record of C.P. Mountford’s Central Australian journey with a group of desert Aborigines. From the original footage the two popular sound films, “Walkabout” and “Tjurunga”, were compiled. “Brown men and red sand” (if projected at silent speed) shows the movements of the Aborigines, especially in the sequences dealing with tribal ceremonies and dances, more naturally than in the sound films, where the movements look jerky.
results.creator_credit_for_label: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau

results.title: Brown coal to kilowatts
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Classroom film describing the processes by which wet, raw brown coal from the Yallourn open cut is burned in specially designed boilers to produce steam for use in turbines for the generation of electric power. Laboratory demonstration, models, and diagrams explain the principles of operation of plant seen in use at Yallourn.

results.title: Brown coal to briquettes
results.creator_credit: Frank Hurley and State Electricity Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: Classroom film showing the manufacture of briquettes at Yallourn and Morwell Victoria. Includes demonstration by models of processes; operation of coal dredges at open cut; crushing and drying of coal; pressing of fine powder into briquettes; transport of finished product to other parts of Victoria.

results.title: Brown bears go fishing
results.brief_description: This film aims to stimulate interest in reading and to increase the vocabulary of primary pupils by using over prints and repetition in the narration. While reading and looking at storybooks, a group of children learn about the habits of polar bears and American black bears. Shows Alaskan brown bears swimming in a stream, catching and eating salmon, fighting over fish and teaching cubs how to swim.

results.title: Brothers Manakia - Pioneers of Greek and Balkan Cinema
results.brief_description: This film traces the history of Yannis and Miltos Manakia, beginning at their place of birth, the Macedonian village of Abdela, where the first Greek film “The Weavers” was made by the Manakia brothers in 1905, laying the foundations of the Greek and Balkan Cinema.

results.title: Brothers keeper [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Bruce Sinofsky, Joe Berlinger, American Playhouse Theatrical Films and Hand to Mouth Productions
results.brief_description: This award-winning documentary focuses on a controversial murder trial that took place in the Upstate New York farming community of Munnsville in 1990. 59 year old Delbert Ward, one of four reclusive, eccentric brothers who shared the same dilapidated two-room shack on their dairy farm for over 60 years, was accused of murder when his ailing older brother was found dead in the bed they shared. After being interrogated by the state police, the simple-minded and barely literate Delbert signed a confession stating that he smothered his brother as an act of mercy. Believing him incapable of murder, and not possessing the mental capacity to understand police bureaucracy, the local community rallied around Delbert and his brothers, raising bail in a matter of hours. The film covers the period between Delbert’s arrest and his trial, focusing on the daily lives of the ‘Ward boys’ as national media scrutiny intensifies around them. As the state police gather ‘evidence’ that incest was a motive for the killing, the local community’s support for the outcast Ward brothers strengthens. Interviews with state police and prosecuters, local residents and Delbert’s lawyer build the case for and against the accused. An intriguing, compelling and unashamedly subjective real-life murder mystery that goes beyond simply telling a good story to reveal the part the media plays in the formation of personal and community identity.
